insights.summary: NeuroReach VR utilizes multimodal feedback and adaptive training to enhance motor recovery in stroke patients.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system employs a combination of visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to train stroke survivors in reach and grasp tasks, such as pouring and tracing (c0001, c0004). This interactive approach aims to improve selective muscle activation in the arms, a critical component for regaining functional movement post-stroke (c0001, c0004). The system's adaptive controller dynamically adjusts training parameters based on user performance, and feedback mechanisms are designed to gradually transition from performance-based to results-based cues as the patient progresses (c0002). This adaptive nature, coupled with detailed performance logging, allows for personalized and effective rehabilitation.

1
NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

insights.summary: Technical challenges in system development and validation require ongoing attention for clinical efficacy.
insights.text: Despite the promising design, the NeuroReach VR system faces several technical hurdles that need to be addressed for its successful clinical implementation (c0001). These include potential issues like anchor drift and noisy tilt estimation, which are being mitigated through solutions such as re-localization and filtering (c0003). Furthermore, the system's adaptive difficulty and metric consistency present ongoing challenges, requiring careful management to avoid overreactive oscillations and ensure reliable progress tracking across sessions (c0001). Crucially, the system is still in development and has not yet undergone clinical validation, highlighting the need for further research to confirm its effectiveness (c0001).

insights.summary: The system's adaptive features and feedback mechanisms are central to its rehabilitation approach, though their specific implementation requires further evidence.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system is designed with an adaptive controller and feedback fading mechanisms intended to optimize training for stroke patients (c0002). While the system incorporates specific feedback elements like halos and ticks, and aims to adjust difficulty, the detailed evidence for the adaptive nature and the gradual fading process of these feedback mechanisms is not fully elaborated (c0002). Similarly, the claim that the system directly trains selective muscle activation is supported by the goal of improving arm function, but the evidence primarily focuses on the broader feedback and adaptation strategies rather than the direct physiological training of specific muscles (c0004).

validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].

actions.title: Investigate the impact of adaptive difficulty oscillation on user engagement and learning.
actions.detail: The system's adaptive controller can lead to overreactive difficulty oscillation (c0003). Further research is needed to understand how this oscillation affects stroke patients' motivation, frustration levels, and the effectiveness of motor learning. This could involve user studies to observe behavioral responses and qualitative feedback.

actions.title: Hypothesize the optimal parameters for feedback fading to maximize motor skill acquisition.
actions.detail: The system employs feedback fading from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results (c0002). However, the specific parameters and timing of this fading process are not detailed. We hypothesize that there are optimal rates and thresholds for feedback fading that will lead to more robust and generalized motor skill acquisition in stroke survivors. This could be tested by varying the fading speed and observing long-term retention of learned movements.

actions.title: Conduct a pilot clinical validation study to assess the efficacy of NeuroReach VR in improving selective muscle activation.
actions.detail: While the system aims to improve selective muscle activation (c0001, c0004), the current evidence indicates it has not yet been clinically validated (c0001). A pilot study is a crucial next step to gather preliminary data on the system's effectiveness in a clinical setting, specifically measuring improvements in selective muscle activation through objective biomechanical analysis and functional outcome measures.

actions.title: Clarify the specific mechanisms and metrics used to quantify 'selective muscle activation' improvement.
actions.detail: The claim states the system aims to improve selective muscle activation (c0001, c0004), but the evidence focuses on broader feedback and adaptation rather than direct muscle activation training (c0004). It is unclear how this specific outcome is measured and what metrics are used to demonstrate improvement. Clarification is needed on the biomechanical or electrophysiological measures employed to assess selective muscle activation.

actions.title: Develop and test strategies to ensure metric consistency across sessions to prevent drift.
actions.detail: The system faces challenges with metric drift across sessions (c0003), which could impact the reliability of performance tracking and adaptive adjustments. Next steps should involve developing and rigorously testing specific strategies, such as recalibration protocols or baseline normalization techniques, to ensure consistent and reliable metric reporting over time.

challenges.claim_text: NeuroReach VR is a mixed-reality system designed to train stroke patients in reach and grasp using tasks like pouring and tracing, incorporating visual, auditory, and haptic feedback. The system aims to improve selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors through these interactive training methods. The training environment is gamified, featuring intuitive feedback mechanisms and motivational elements that have potential for clinical application. Demonstrations include live on-headset sessions with real-time feedback like halos, ticks, and error bars, alongside a projected dashboard displaying performance metrics.
challenges.summary: The evidence suggests the system is still in development and has not yet been clinically validated.
challenges.detail: The provided evidence snippets describe work packages for developing an adaptive controller and logging system (Weeks 6-8) and a pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9-12). This indicates the system is in the research and development phase and has not yet undergone extensive clinical trials or demonstrated proven efficacy in a real-world patient population. challenges.claim_text: NeuroReach VR is a mixed-reality system designed to train stroke patients in reach and grasp using tasks like pouring and tracing, incorporating visual, auditory, and haptic feedback. The system aims to improve selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors through these interactive training methods. The training environment is gamified, featuring intuitive feedback mechanisms and motivational elements that have potential for clinical application. Demonstrations include live on-headset sessions with real-time feedback like halos, ticks, and error bars, alongside a projected dashboard displaying performance metrics.
challenges.summary: The evidence highlights challenges with the system's adaptive difficulty and metric consistency.
challenges.detail: Evidence E1 explicitly mentions 'Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions.' This directly contradicts the claim's implication of a stable and intuitive training environment. If the difficulty fluctuates erratically or performance metrics are inconsistent, it could hinder effective training and patient motivation, undermining the system's stated goals of improving muscle activation and providing a positive user experience.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error
